name: brassica-oleracea-gemmifera
definition: The Brussels sprout is a member of the Gemmifera Group of cabbages, grown for its edible buds.
description:
Brussels sprouts are a cultivar of cabbage grown for their edible small leafy green buds, which resemble miniature cabbages.

The plant has long, smooth and leathery leaves which can be green to purple in color and are arranged alternately on the stem.

The sprouts form at the base of each leaf, in a long, spiral stem.

The edible portion of the crop is the bud, typically 1.5 to 4.0 centimeters in diameter, which is a small cabbage-like head.

Most varieties have green sprouts, but red-leaved varieties have also been developed.

Brussels sprouts are high in fiber, vitamins, minerals and antioxidants, making them a nutritious addition to your diet.

They may also come with added health benefits, including the potential to reduce the risk of cancer, decrease inflammation and improve blood sugar control.

For breast cancer in particular, eating Brussels sprout might change the way estrogen is used in the body.

Brussels sprouts usually are eaten cooked, and the small young sprouts have a more delicate flavour than older ones.

The most common method of preparing Brussels sprouts for cooking begins with cutting the buds off the stalk.

Any surplus stem is cut away, and any loose surface leaves are peeled and discarded.

Once cut and cleaned, the buds are typically cooked by boiling, steaming, stir frying, grilling, slow cooking, or roasting.

To ensure even cooking throughout, buds of a similar size are usually chosen.

Some cooks make a single cut or a cross in the center of the stem to aid the penetration of heat.

Though commonly grown as annuals, Brussels sprouts are biennial plants and will produce yellow flowers with four petals if kept for two seasons.

Seeds are borne in silique fruits.

The plant requires a mild cool climate and is harmed by hot weather.

In its seedling stage and early development, the plant closely resembles the common cabbage.

From that, the main stem grows and the auxiliary buds along the stem develop into small heads (sprouts).

Once harvested, sprouts last 3 to 5 weeks under ideal near-freezing conditions before wilting and discoloring, and about half as long at refrigerator temperature.

Although native to the Mediterranean region with other cabbage species, Brussels sprouts first appeared in northern Europe during the 5th century.

Later, in the 13th century, sprouts started being cultivated near Brussels, from which they derived their name.

First recorded description of the Brussels sprouts dates to 1587.

contextual.caption: Brussels sprouts grow in temperature ranges of 7 to 24 °C. Fields are ready for harvest 90 to 180 days after planting.

featured.caption: Brussels sprout can reach 60 to 100 centimeters in height with a spread of 50 to 60 centimeters.

related.definition: Cabbage is a leafy green, red (purple), or white (pale green) biennial plant grown as an annual vegetable crop for its dense-leaved heads.
Broccoli is an edible green plant in the cabbage family whose large flowering head and stalk is eaten as a vegetable.
